UnitType.Backstory: Ogres take decades to reach their full height and weight, but their young, though significantly smaller, are to be considered equally dangerous, for what they lack in size they more than make up for in belligerence. They are even more drawn to gold and precious objects than their mature counterparts, and many a traveler has met their end trying to part an ogre from their treasure.

Ogres are huge, tremendously powerful monsters, giants driven by the most basic of needs; hunger, shelter, lust. Reclusive, territorial, they are believed to be at least as intelligent as trolls, though the sages do not suggest engaging them in conversation... or combat, for that matter, unless one is prepared to fight to the death.
Ogres are infatuated with gildar and are known to carry it with them.

Bone Ogres are mighty creatures that live in the deepest of volcanic vents, seeking - according to some - a refuge similar to that they are said to have been born and bred in... the underground labryinth of N'it'Vaganesh. Bone Ogres are reclusive and only emerge from their dark, warm caverns on rare occasions. When they do, however, woe to anything and anyone nearby.

These are primitive creatures, born, so it is said, within the dungeons of Morrigan the Mad. Slightly larger than men, they are belligerent, dim-witted, and prone to prey on the weak and the unwary.
Troll Ears are used in various alchemical remedies and experiments and can often be sold for a healthy amount of gildar.

Troll Warriors are the hunters of their tribes; the strongest, most cunning of their kind. They often serve as bodyguards and enforcers to tribal shamans.
Many Warriors have been known to carry exceptional weaponry, likely plucked from the mangled bodies of fallen foes.

Troll Shamans tend to be the smartest among their kind, making them, almost by default, tribal leaders. Some - in particular those who manage to master a portion of the channeler's art - are revered as near-gods.
An aside; troll shamans tend to be hoarders, and can often be found carrying unique items pilfered from the corpses of slain adventurers.

Within the third quarto of the Varis Reliquaria is contained the spell Anima Tsal Animana - life from lifelessness. This incantation, first mastered by Ereog in his time of solitude, imbues stone with the semblance of life.
This same spell is believed to animate the Sand Golems that wander the wastelands, which are believed to have been created by forces loyal to the Lady Umber in the time immediately before the great Cataclysm, for some dark purpose that was never fulfilled.
When a Sand Golem is destroyed it reverts back to the rock and sand it was prior to enchantment.

Within the third quarto of the Varis Reliquaria is contained the spell Anima Tsal Animana - life from lifelessness. This incantation, first mastered by Ereog in his time of solitude, imbues stone with the semblance of life, creating creatures that have come to be known as golems.
The simpler golems are controlled by the channeler who creates them, and will return to an inert state if the Channeler is killed or is otherwise unable to maintain control.
When a Golem is destroyed, it reverts back to the normal rock it was prior to enchantment.

GameItemType.Description: Crystal blades that slice through metal with ease

UnitType.Backstory:
Within the third quarto of the Varis Reliquaria is contained the spell Anima Tsal Animana - life from lifelessness. This incantation, first mastered by Ereog in his time of solitude, imbues stone with the semblance of life, creating creatures that have come to be known as golems.
The simpler golems are controlled by the channeler who creates them, and will return to an inert state if the Channeler is killed or is otherwise unable to maintain control.
When a Golem is destroyed, it reverts back to the normal rock it was prior to enchantment.

It is believed that the Anima Tsa Animana - the spell of life from lifelessness - animates these, the rarest of Elemental's golems, though some among the Padars say that it is the soul of a once-living being that inhabits these creatures. Crafted from volcanic glass or lava rock, these creatures are most often found among the ruins of the great cities of man, though from time to time they are uncovered in more unusual locales.
When an Obsidian Golem is destroyed it reverts back to the lava rock it was prior to enchantment.

UnitType.Description: There are few creatures on Elemental that are able to withstand more damage than an War Golem. Long have they stood silent, patient sentry over their charges.
UnitType.Backstory: These are creatures forged of mana and metal; beings who can be summoned into existence only by those possessing the blood of the Aivernach - the Iron Tribes of old. An Iron Golem can wield any weapon given to it, and is a master of defense; long after the last men of Aivern fell to the hordes of Meergas Maz Adul's Nerazga, its Iron Golems remained, stalwart protectors of the city walls.

These are Darklings who have undergone their tribe's rite of passage; they receive a primitive tattoo - a half-circle of white ink, upon the left forearm, on completion of this rite. The meaning of this tattoo is lost to history. To some, it symbolizes Ludra, the moon, and is said to represent the passage of the seasons... a literal coming of age. To others, the half circle represents the Sigil of Curgen - the white eye - and is proof that Darklings were made by the Titans in their own image, and are thus destined to rule Elemental alongside their Fallen brethren... once the last man is wiped from the face of the world.

These are Darklings who have undergone their tribe's rite of passage; they receive a primitive tattoo - a half-circle of white ink, upon the left forearm, on completion of this rite. The meaning of this tattoo is lost to history. To some, it symbolizes Ludra, the moon, and is said to represent the passage of the seasons... a literal coming of age. To others, the half circle represents the Sigil of Curgen - the white eye - and is proof that Darklings were made by the Titans in their own image, and are thus destined to rule Elemental alongside their Fallen brethren... once the last man is wiped from the face of the world.

A select few Darkling warriors are chosen for the honor of becoming Warg riders; these are not necessarily the strongest or most powerful, but rather those Darklings who can master these beasts of burden solely through force of will. The ceremony during which these riders are chosen is among the bloodiest spectacles in all of Elemental.

UnitType.Description: Darkling Shamans gain levels and traits as champions and can learn basic spells.
UnitType.Backstory: Darkling shamans are alternately shunned and revered by their people; they are the oldest, and physically weakest among their tribe, and often scorned for their frailty. Yet the more powerful among them may be respected as well, both for the accumulated wisdom of their years, and for the knowledge they have gained of the channeler's art. All darklings who become shamans of their tribes can cast Blindness and Curse.

These brutally strong creatures are normally found only in the highest peaks of the world but sometimes wander to lower heights when distressed. Argynn said of them: "they have the strength of a hundred men and the temper of a hundred scorned maidens."

These shrills are said to be constructs made by Morrigan the Mad, in the laboratories of N'it'Vaganesh - his attempts to manufacture monsters to rival the giant spiders that the Titan Curgen kept at his beck and call. The air shrill derives its power from the Air Shard.
Their mandibles are potent magical reagents; practicing alchemists and wizards will pay top gildar for them.

These shrills are said to be constructs made by Morrigan the Mad, in the laboratories of N'it'Vaganesh - his attempts to manufacture monsters to rival the giant spiders that the Titan Curgen kept at his beck and call. The Earth shrill derives its power from the Earth Shard.
Their mandibles are potent magical reagents; practicing alchemists and wizards will pay top gildar for them.

These shrills are said to be constructs made by Morrigan the Mad, in the laboratories of N'it'Vaganesh - his attempts to manufacture monsters to rival the giant spiders that the Titan Curgen kept at his beck and call. Though they aren't powerful attackers, their ability to summon torrents of fire can be devastating if they aren't dealt with quickly.

These shrills are said to be constructs made by Morrigan the Mad, in the laboratories of N'it'Vaganesh - his attempts to manufacture monsters to rival the giant spiders that the Titan Curgen kept at his beck and call. The water shrill derives its power from the Water Shard.
Their mandibles are potent magical reagents; practicing alchemists and wizards will pay top gildar for them.

UnitType.Description:
Catapults are devastating on the battle field but are extremely slow and expensive. Their attacks damage all units within a 1 tile radius.
The Light Catapult is quicker to load and more accurare that typical Catapults.
UnitType.Backstory: These machines are based upon drawings found in the great library at New Pariden. They are reconstructions of those catapults Argynn used thousands of years ago during the siege of Eduruun V'olloz - the black citadel of the Nerazga.

UnitType.Description:
Catapults are devastating on the battle field but are extremely slow and expensive. Their attacks damage all units within a 1 tile radius.
The Destroyer Catapult is more accurate and packs an even bigger punch that typical Catapults.
UnitType.Backstory: These machines are based upon drawings found in the great library at New Pariden. They are reconstructions of those catapults Argynn used thousands of years ago during the siege of Eduruun V'olloz - the black citadel of the Nerazga.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakeable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. 'It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Aygethos value labor, loyalty and discipline - but most, the sword and spear. They see that sorcerers again have brought war to Elemental, proof again that magic is not to be trusted. In battle, the spear men of Aygethos will prove their superiority over the arcane.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: All kingdoms long for peace and prosperity that in these times seem an impossibility, but it is the Siirdi who believe it is their destiny. Descended from the great nation of Sirionne, these people seek to re-establish the Holy Kingdom because it is faith in the Light that will once again unite the races of men.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The Nothari lost their treasured iceland homeland to the cataclysm. As nomads they have managed to survive - but it is the lack of assistance from the other nations that the Nothari remember the most. Now under Myrthani they are tending a beautiful new homeland. Relations with other Kingdoms may prove more difficult to grow.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Raktur can trace their bloodline back to the time of the Magi. The origin of their affinity with fire however, is uncertain. Some say they are descended from the Magi themselves, other that it is an old hint of dragon in their blood. Now, after the cataclysm, the Raktur hope to recover the secrets of their birthright in flame.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: Few races know the cost of war like the Dremorian people. One hundred years of war with the trolls has decimated their once great nation. The Dremorian affinity with earth and forest and beast made the Cataclysm's destruction almost too much for them to bear. Now, their spears are kept sharp and scouts alert, for their history tells them the endurance of peace is but leaves in the wind.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Urns have always had a close affinity to nature, preferring open fields and woodland groves to city streets. And now after the cataclysm the Urns elders hear the lament of those few surviving trees. As these fledgling forests struggle to recover from Cataclysm, the guardians of Urns will ensure any who threaten the trees die swiftly.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Otaran are not known as warriors. They are skilled craftsmen and a studied people, believing in logic and reason, and that power comes though knowledge and understanding. By their knowledge, the Otaran mastered the lost arts of alchemy and golem craft. Should the war in Elemental arrive in Otaran, its scholars shall be ready to defend themselves.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Cormenlon fancy themselves as more cultured than most, for Cormenlon is a wealthy nation, with some of the largest and advanced cities in Elemental. Diplomacy and accounting are widely considered more useful skills than swordsmanship. Yet the might of arms will be needed to keep Fallen and men alike at bay, now that war again brews in Elemental...

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The Xaroch are a new people, their origins a mystery having only appeared on Elemental following the cataclysm. They are intelligent and patient, living longer lifespan than the other races. This longevity and a natural affinity with the arcane also breeds an unhealthy arrogance and distaste towards the other races, particularly the obnoxious and unpredictable races of men.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: Of all the Fallen it is the beastmen of Thuhl that epitomize the ethos of the Empires: the strong rule, the weak suffer. They are cruel and savage, killing themselves as often as other races. But now, under the dominance of the warlord Bhargol, the united Thuhl tribes may rule all of Elemental.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: When the Nothari people were almost destroyed during the cataclysm, not all survivors followed Myrthani to search for a new home. A faithless lot chose the underground as their new home. In these dark tunnels their faith in shadows was rewarded, and the Sholdari were born.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: Asrillorgue was an affluent and scholarly nation. But then came Rastmore, with whispers of the Drednii, and he built a cult of feverish loyalty. Now Rastmore leads through his dark arts. And the Drednii demons he speaks for, they hunger for far more than just Asrillorgue...

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: Often mistaken for their Fallen kin the Trogs, the warriors of Gorgal adopt a more strategic view of the world. They know that there can be a time for planning, and a use for allies. The Gorgal have forged pacts with many of the twisted creatures of Elemental, and this strength of numbers may bring them control of the world.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The Morquai are an accomplished people ruled by an autocratic noble class. Prior to the cataclysm, the Empire was experiencing a golden age - but the nobles are threatened by the current Empress Ritheria. Coming to power in questionable circumstance, she has grand designs for the future of the Morquai she keeps dearly secret.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: The Gaush barbarian tribes started as little more than raiding savages, attacking caravans and pillaging towns to survive. Constant warring amongst themselves has filtered out the weak, and focused their culture on warfare. Now the Gaush are united, and will subsist upon the greater cities of Elemental.

UnitType.Description: Grenadiers hurl the dangerous Hellfire Bombs at enemy troops.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. 'It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. As compared to other faction's horsemen the Knights are known for their speed and are often able to sweep over enemy spellcasters and archers before they have a chance to act.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. They are driven into a frenzy at the smell of blood and many commanders use archers to direct their attacks.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. The Tide is known for nipping at the heels of powerful enemies. The tactic is frequently suicide, but unquestioningly effective.
UnitType.Backstory:
"Now you are the whirlwind; warg and rider, one flesh from two. Reap me a harvest of bright, red blood." - The Enchantress
These are mounted units of the Wraith army; warriors upon wargs, whose unearthly speed and savage ferocity have given rise to rumors of cannibalism upon the battliefield.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Aygethos value labor, loyalty and discipline - but most, the sword and spear. They see that sorcerers again have brought war to Elemental, proof again that magic is not to be trusted. In battle, the spear men of Aygethos will prove their superiority over the arcane.

They are intelligent and patient, living longer lifespan than the other races. This longevity and a natural affinity with the arcane also breeds an unhealthy arrogance and distaste towards the other races, particularly the obnoxious and unpredictable races of men.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. They are driven into a frenzy at the smell of blood and many commanders use archers to direct their attacks.
UnitType.Backstory: Of all the Fallen it is the beastmen of Thuhl that epitomize the ethos of the Empires: the strong rule, the weak suffer. They are cruel and savage, killing themselves as often as other races. But now, under the dominance of the warlord Bhargol, the united Thuhl tribes may rule all of Elemental.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. The Tide is known for nipping at the heels of powerful enemies. The tactic is frequently suicide, but unquestioningly effective.
UnitType.Backstory: When the Nothari people were almost destroyed during the cataclysm, not all survivors followed Myrthani to search for a new home. A faithless lot chose the underground as their new home. In these dark tunnels their faith in shadows was rewarded, and the Sholdari were born.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: Asrillorgue was an affluent and scholarly nation. But then came Rastmore, with whispers of the Drednii, and he built a cult of feverish loyalty. Now Rastmore leads through his dark arts. And the Drednii demons he speaks for, they hunger for far more than just Asrillorgue...

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: Often mistaken for their Fallen kin the Trogs, the warriors of Gorgal adopt a more strategic view of the world. They know that there can be a time for planning, and a use for allies. The Gorgal have forged pacts with many of the twisted creatures of Elemental, and this strength of numbers may bring them control of the world.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: The Morquai are an accomplished people ruled by an autocratic noble class. Prior to the cataclysm, the Empire was experiencing a golden age - but the nobles are threatened by the current Empress Ritheria. Coming to power in questionable circumstance, she has grand designs for the future of the Morquai she keeps dearly secret.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: The Gaush barbarian tribes started as little more than raiding savages, attacking caravans and pillaging towns to survive. Constant warring amongst themselves has filtered out the weak, and focused their culture on warfare. Now the Gaush are united, and will subsist upon the greater cities of Elemental.

UnitType.Description: Border Guard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

The Wizards Eye is the creation of magicians from ages past. With a series of complicated incantations, a mage can summon a Wizards Eye miles from their own location. This enables the mage to use the Eye to scout distant lands without endangering themselves.

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.

UnitType.Backstory: The people of Aygethos value labor, loyalty and discipline - but most, the sword and spear. They see that sorcerers again have brought war to Elemental, proof again that magic is not to be trusted. In battle, the spear men of Aygethos will prove their superiority over the arcane.

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.
UnitType.Backstory: All kingdoms long for peace and prosperity that in these times seem an impossibility, but it is the Siirdi who believe it is their destiny. Descended from the great nation of Sirionne, these people seek to re-establish the Holy Kingdom because it is faith in the Light that will once again unite the races of men.

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.
UnitType.Backstory: The Nothari lost their treasured iceland homeland to the cataclysm. As nomads they have managed to survive - but it is the lack of assistance from the other nations that the Nothari remember the most. Now under Myrthani they are tending a beautiful new homeland. Relations with other Kingdoms may prove more difficult to grow.

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Raktur can trace their bloodline back to the time of the Magi. The origin of their affinity with fire however, is uncertain. Some say they are descended from the Magi themselves, other that it is an old hint of dragon in their blood. Now, after the cataclysm, the Raktur hope to recover the secrets of their birthright in flame.

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.
UnitType.Backstory: Few races know the cost of war like the Dremorian people. One hundred years of war with the trolls has decimated their once great nation. The Dremorian affinity with earth and forest and beast made the Cataclysm's destruction almost too much for them to bear. Now, their spears are kept sharp and scouts alert, for their history tells them the endurance of peace is but leaves in the wind.

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Urns have always had a close affinity to nature, preferring open fields and woodland groves to city streets. And now after the cataclysm the Urns elders hear the lament of those few surviving trees. As these fledgling forests struggle to recover from Cataclysm, the guardians of Urns will ensure any who threaten the trees die swiftly.

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Otaran are not known as warriors. They are skilled craftsmen and a studied people, believing in logic and reason, and that power comes though knowledge and understanding. By their knowledge, the Otaran mastered the lost arts of alchemy and golem craft. Should the war in Elemental arrive in Otaran, its scholars shall be ready to defend themselves.

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Cormenlon fancy themselves as more cultured than most, for Cormenlon is a wealthy nation, with some of the largest and advanced cities in Elemental. Diplomacy and accounting are widely considered more useful skills than swordsmanship. Yet the might of arms will be needed to keep Fallen and men alike at bay, now that war again brews in Elemental...

UnitType.Description: The Guild Assassin is a fast and deadly foe, able to utilise a number of special attacks in combat.
Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory:
"It is a sea of lances I spy in the morning fog; a formation that comes ever, ever closer. I fear for our army, my love; I fear for our country, and yes, I fear for my own life as well." - Duc Lonte, 13th Baron of Ithul, writing to his wife as he prepared to battle the assembled armies of Sodesh Jushi, warlord of the Trogs.
The Gray March are the spearmen of the Trog (D'Rog) army; though they often form the front line of defense, these soldiers are not content to merely await attack, but will often be found initiating it.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory:
"It is a sea of lances I spy in the morning fog; a formation that comes ever, ever closer. I fear for our army, my love; I fear for our country, and yes, I fear for my own life as well." - Duc Lonte, 13th Baron of Ithul, writing to his wife as he prepared to battle the assembled armies of Sodesh Jushi, warlord of the Trogs.
The Gray March are the spearmen of the Trog (D'Rog) army; though they often form the front line of defense, these soldiers are not content to merely await attack, but will often be found initiating it.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Templars provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: All kingdoms long for peace and prosperity that in these times seem an impossibility, but it is the Siirdi who believe it is their destiny. Descended from the great nation of Sirionne, these people seek to re-establish the Holy Kingdom because it is faith in the Light that will once again unite the races of men.

UnitType.Description: Acolytes provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The Nothari lost their treasured iceland homeland to the cataclysm. As nomads they have managed to survive - but it is the lack of assistance from the other nations that the Nothari remember the most. Now under Myrthani they are tending a beautiful new homeland. Relations with other Kingdoms may prove more difficult to grow.

UnitType.Description: Acolytes provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Raktur can trace their bloodline back to the time of the Magi. The origin of their affinity with fire however, is uncertain. Some say they are descended from the Magi themselves, other that it is an old hint of dragon in their blood. Now, after the cataclysm, the Raktur hope to recover the secrets of their birthright in flame.

UnitType.Description: Shepherds provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Few races know the cost of war like the Dremorian people. One hundred years of war with the trolls has decimated their once great nation. The Dremorian affinity with earth and forest and beast made the Cataclysm's destruction almost too much for them to bear. Now, their spears are kept sharp and scouts alert, for their history tells them the endurance of peace is but leaves in the wind.

UnitType.Description: Druids provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Urns have always had a close affinity to nature, preferring open fields and woodland groves to city streets. And now after the cataclysm the Urns elders hear the lament of those few surviving trees. As these fledgling forests struggle to recover from Cataclysm, the guardians of Urns will ensure any who threaten the trees die swiftly.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Otaran are not known as warriors. They are skilled craftsmen and a studied people, believing in logic and reason, and that power comes though knowledge and understanding. By their knowledge, the Otaran mastered the lost arts of alchemy and golem craft. Should the war in Elemental arrive in Otaran, its scholars shall be ready to defend themselves.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The people of Cormenlon fancy themselves as more cultured than most, for Cormenlon is a wealthy nation, with some of the largest and advanced cities in Elemental. Diplomacy and accounting are widely considered more useful skills than swordsmanship. Yet the might of arms will be needed to keep Fallen and men alike at bay, now that war again brews in Elemental...

UnitType.Description: Magi provide arcance support to armies, able to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The Xaroch are a new people, their origins a mystery having only appeared on Elemental following the cataclysm. They are intelligent and patient, living longer lifespan than the other races. This longevity and a natural affinity with the arcane also breeds an unhealthy arrogance and distaste towards the other races, particularly the obnoxious and unpredictable races of men.

UnitType.Description: Cabalists provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Of all the Fallen it is the beastmen of Thuhl that epitomize the ethos of the Empires: the strong rule, the weak suffer. They are cruel and savage, killing themselves as often as other races. But now, under the dominance of the warlord Bhargol, the united Thuhl tribes may rule all of Elemental.

UnitType.Description: Cultist provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: When the Nothari people were almost destroyed during the cataclysm, not all survivors followed Myrthani to search for a new home. A faithless lot chose the underground as their new home. In these dark tunnels their faith in shadows was rewarded, and the Sholdari were born.

UnitType.Description: Ritualist provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Asrillorgue was an affluent and scholarly nation. But then came Rastmore, with whispers of the Drednii, and he built a cult of feverish loyalty. Now Rastmore leads through his dark arts. And the Drednii demons he speaks for, they hunger for far more than just Asrillorgue...

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: Often mistaken for their Fallen kin the Trogs, the warriors of Gorgal adopt a more strategic view of the world. They know that there can be a time for planning, and a use for allies. The Gorgal have forged pacts with many of the twisted creatures of Elemental, and this strength of numbers may bring them control of the world.

UnitType.Description: Initiates provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The Morquai are an accomplished people ruled by an autocratic noble class. Prior to the cataclysm, the Empire was experiencing a golden age - but the nobles are threatened by the current Empress Ritheria. Coming to power in questionable circumstance, she has grand designs for the future of the Morquai she keeps dearly secret.

UnitType.Description: Disciples provide spiritual support to armies, able to utilise Faith to invoke spell like abilities.
UnitType.Backstory: The Gaush barbarian tribes started as little more than raiding savages, attacking caravans and pillaging towns to survive. Constant warring amongst themselves has filtered out the weak, and focused their culture on warfare. Now the Gaush are united, and will subsist upon the greater cities of Elemental.

UnitType.Description: Harridan Riders are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. The Tide is known for nipping at the heels of powerful enemies. The tactic is frequently suicide, but unquestioningly effective.
